20110103210911.000|20110103210913.000|TR0|ALISON KOSIK, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Exactly. 
20110103210913.000|20110103210916.000|TR0| And just so you know, if you're looking 
20110103210916.000|20110103210918.000|TR0|to book a flight on American Airlines, I 
20110103210918.000|20110103210920.000|TR0|wouldn't go to Expedia or Orbitz, because 
20110103210920.000|20110103210922.000|TR0|you're not going to find those flights 
20110103210922.000|20110103210925.000|TR0|listed there.  Basically, Expedia and 
20110103210925.000|20110103210927.000|TR0|Orbitz have kicked American Airlines to 
20110103210927.000|20110103210929.000|TR0|the curb.
20110103210929.000|20110103210931.000|TR0|
20110103210931.000|20110103210934.000|TR0|It's a really a battle that's been brewing 
20110103210934.000|20110103210936.000|TR0|over the past few weeks. It's a battle 
20110103210936.000|20110103210938.000|TR0|over fees, Brooke, one that the online 
20110103210938.000|20110103210940.000|TR0|travel sites charge airlines.  So, they're 
20110103210940.000|20110103210943.000|TR0|at odds as to how many fees they should be 
20110103210943.000|20110103210945.000|TR0|charged.  And as for consumers, it really 
20110103210945.000|20110103210947.000|TR0|makes it harder to find the best deal 
20110103210947.000|20110103210949.000|TR0|because what's going to essentially 
20110103210949.000|20110103210952.000|TR0|happens is you're going to have to go to 
20110103210952.000|20110103210954.000|TR0|each individual airline site to find a 
20110103210954.000|20110103210956.000|TR0|fare like we did in the old days.
20110103210956.000|20110103210958.000|TR0|
20110103210958.000|20110103211001.000|TR0|But keep in mind, you can still find 
20110103211001.000|20110103211003.000|TR0|American Airlines fares on other sites 
20110103211003.000|20110103211005.000|TR0|like kayak.com and Priceline -- Brooke.

20110103211014.000|20110103211017.000|TR0|KOSIK:  It really is, because, you know, 
20110103211017.000|20110103211019.000|TR0|if you think of the online travel industry 
20110103211019.000|20110103211021.000|TR0|as a whole -- well, it's pitting them 
20110103211021.000|20110103211023.000|TR0|against the airlines.  But, you know, it's 
20110103211023.000|20110103211026.000|TR0|turning into kind of a game of chicken and 
20110103211026.000|20110103211028.000|TR0|we're going to see who the last one 
20110103211028.000|20110103211030.000|TR0|standing is going to be because, you know, 
20110103211030.000|20110103211032.000|TR0|the airlines need these sites almost as 
20110103211032.000|20110103211035.000|TR0|much as the sites need the airlines.
20110103211035.000|20110103211037.000|TR0|
20110103211037.000|20110103211039.000|TR0|And who's going to lose in the end?  It's 
20110103211039.000|20110103211041.000|TR0|going to be the consumer because we're 
20110103211041.000|20110103211044.000|TR0|going to have do more work finding the 
20110103211044.000|20110103211046.000|TR0|best rates and we're not necessarily going 
20110103211046.000|20110103211048.000|TR0|to find the best rates because we don't 
20110103211048.000|20110103211050.000|TR0|have this one aggregate site.
20110103211050.000|20110103211053.000|TR0|

20110103211055.000|20110103211057.000|TR0|-- pushing this along because they really 
20110103211057.000|20110103211059.000|TR0|also want to have more control over these 
20110103211059.000|20110103211102.000|TR0|fares.  They also want to have the ability

20110103215332.000|20110103215335.000|TR0|discount the gravity of the offense.  But 
20110103215335.000|20110103215337.000|TR0|given Nunez's limited role in Santos' 
20110103215337.000|20110103215339.000|TR0|death, and considering that Nunez had no 
20110103215339.000|20110103215342.000|TR0|criminal record prior to this offense, I 
20110103215342.000|20110103215344.000|TR0|believe Nunez's sentence is excessive."
20110103215344.000|20110103215346.000|TR0|
20110103215346.000|20110103215348.000|TR0|So, Sunny, does this commutation strike 
20110103215348.000|20110103215351.000|TR0|you as questionable?
20110103215351.000|20110103215353.000|TR0|
20110103215353.000|20110103215355.000|TR0|HOSTIN:  It really does.  It real strikes 
20110103215355.000|20110103215357.000|TR0|me as questionable, Brooke, because, of 
20110103215357.000|20110103215400.000|TR0|course, there is  a sound legal basis 
20110103215400.000|20110103215402.000|TR0|because governors do have this pardon 
20110103215402.000|20110103215404.000|TR0|power.  But that power is typically 
20110103215404.000|20110103215406.000|TR0|reserved for those egregious cases that 
20110103215406.000|20110103215409.000|TR0|sort of offend your sense of justice.
20110103215409.000|20110103215411.000|TR0|
20110103215411.000|20110103215413.000|TR0|When I look at the facts of this case, 
20110103215413.000|20110103215415.000|TR0|given the fact that he did stab someone 
20110103215415.000|20110103215418.000|TR0|who just happened to survive, and there 
20110103215418.000|20110103215420.000|TR0|was a 22-year-old that died from this, it 
20110103215420.000|20110103215422.000|TR0|doesn't offend my sense of justice that he 
20110103215422.000|20110103215424.000|TR0|received a 16-year sentence.  What does 
20110103215424.000|20110103215427.000|TR0|appear questionable is the access. That 
20110103215427.000|20110103215429.000|TR0|is, a politician's access to the governor.
20110103215429.000|20110103215431.000|TR0|
20110103215431.000|20110103215433.000|TR0|How is it that Esteban Nunez's paperwork 
20110103215433.000|20110103215436.000|TR0|got to the top of the pardon row?  And 
20110103215436.000|20110103215438.000|TR0|that is very striking, and I think it has 
20110103215438.000|20110103215440.000|TR0|many people sort of scratching their heads 
20110103215440.000|20110103215443.000|TR0|about this one.
20110103215443.000|20110103215445.000|TR0|
20110103215445.000|20110103215447.000|TR0|BALDWIN:  People are scratching their 
20110103215447.000|20110103215449.000|TR0|heads about this one.  Would it be common, 
20110103215449.000|20110103215452.000|TR0|Sunny, for someone who -- as you 
20110103215452.000|20110103215454.000|TR0|mentioned, two people involved here -- 
20110103215454.000|20110103215456.000|TR0|someone who was considered a party to a 
20110103215456.000|20110103215458.000|TR0|murder to get the same sentence the actual 
20110103215458.000|20110103215501.000|TR0|killer got?  Is that common?
20110103215501.000|20110103215503.000|TR0|
20110103215503.000|20110103215505.000|TR0|HOSTIN:  Well, absolutely, it's common, 
20110103215505.000|20110103215507.000|TR0|especially in cases where there's an 
20110103215507.000|20110103215510.000|TR0|accomplice, where there's someone that is 
20110103215510.000|20110103215512.000|TR0|a coconspirator. And in this case, he was 
20110103215512.000|20110103215514.000|TR0|involved in this role.
20110103215514.000|20110103215516.000|TR0|
20110103215516.000|20110103215519.000|TR0|Apparently, they were looking for a fight, 
20110103215519.000|20110103215521.000|TR0|found a fight, and he did stab someone 
20110103215521.000|20110103215523.000|TR0|else who happened to survive.  But for 
20110103215523.000|20110103215525.000|TR0|that, he could have also been convicted or

20110103215528.000|20110103215530.000|TR0|this is a questionable call by the 
20110103215530.000|20110103215532.000|TR0|then-governor.
20110103215532.000|20110103215534.000|TR0|
20110103215534.000|20110103215537.000|TR0|BALDWIN:  A questionable call, says Sunny 
20110103215537.000|20110103215539.000|TR0|Hostin.
20110103215539.000|20110103215541.000|TR0|
20110103215541.000|20110103215544.000|TR0|Case number two.  We have reported on 
20110103215544.000|20110103215546.000|TR0|several people -- I've done some of these 
20110103215546.000|20110103215548.000|TR0|reports -- on exonerees.  These are people 
20110103215548.000|20110103215550.000|TR0|who spent years and years in prison for 
20110103215550.000|20110103215553.000|TR0|crimes they didn't commit.  It always 
20110103215553.000|20110103215555.000|TR0|seems like when they get out, they get 
20110103215555.000|20110103215557.000|TR0|big, big money, big settlements when the 
20110103215557.000|20110103215559.000|TR0|wrongful conviction is discovered and 
20110103215559.000|20110103215602.000|TR0|they're finally set free.
20110103215602.000|20110103215604.000|TR0|
20110103215604.000|20110103215606.000|TR0|But there's this case in Wisconsin that 
20110103215606.000|20110103215608.000|TR0|caught your attention that really calls 
20110103215608.000|20110103215611.000|TR0|into question how much states should pay 
20110103215611.000|20110103215613.000|TR0|innocent people who are put behind bars.  
20110103215613.000|20110103215615.000|TR0|In this case, $25,000 for 23 years in 
20110103215615.000|20110103215617.000|TR0|prison.
20110103215617.000|20110103215620.000|TR0|
20110103215620.000|20110103215622.000|TR0|Twenty-five thousand dollars, I mean, 
20110103215622.000|20110103215624.000|TR0|that's not a lot of money.
20110103215624.000|20110103215626.000|TR0|
20110103215626.000|20110103215629.000|TR0|HOSTIN:  Yes, that's right.  It really did 
20110103215629.000|20110103215631.000|TR0|catch my eye when I looked at it, because, 
20110103215631.000|20110103215633.000|TR0|you know, under the Wisconsin compensation 
20110103215633.000|20110103215635.000|TR0|law, the board is only allowed to give him 
20110103215635.000|20110103215638.000|TR0|$25,000.
20110103215638.000|20110103215640.000|TR0|
20110103215640.000|20110103215642.000|TR0|This is someone that was wrongfully 
20110103215642.000|20110103215645.000|TR0|convicted at the age of 21, and basically 
20110103215645.000|20110103215647.000|TR0|gave up everything -- an education, gave 
20110103215647.000|20110103215649.000|TR0|up his ability to get married, to have a 
20110103215649.000|20110103215651.000|TR0|family.  And then receive $25,000.
20110103215651.000|20110103215654.000|TR0|
20110103215654.000|20110103215656.000|TR0|That's just really not adequate.  And the 
20110103215656.000|20110103215658.000|TR0|board agreed, that it just wasn't 
20110103215658.000|20110103215700.000|TR0|adequate.  But the law didn't allow them 
20110103215700.000|20110103215703.000|TR0|to give him anymore.
20110103215703.000|20110103215705.000|TR0|
20110103215705.000|20110103215707.000|TR0|BALDWIN:  And briefly, before I move on, 
20110103215707.000|20110103215709.000|TR0|if people aren't familiar with these kind 
20110103215709.000|20110103215712.000|TR0|of exoneree stories, other states, I mean, 
20110103215712.000|20110103215714.000|TR0|they give multiple millions to these 
20110103215714.000|20110103215716.000|TR0|exonerees.  Correct?
20110103215716.000|20110103215718.000|TR0|
20110103215718.000|20110103215721.000|TR0|HOSTIN:  Absolutely.  I mean, even in 
20110103215721.000|20110103215723.000|TR0|Florida, a board can give up to $50,000 
20110103215723.000|20110103215725.000|TR0|per year.  And so in a case like this, 
20110103215725.000|20110103215727.000|TR0|that would have been about $2 million, as 
20110103215727.000|20110103215730.000|TR0|opposed to $25,000.  That's about what, a 
20110103215730.000|20110103215732.000|TR0|little over $1,000 per year for your life

20110103215736.000|20110103215739.000|TR0|BALDWIN:  Yes.
20110103215739.000|20110103215741.000|TR0|

20110103215746.000|20110103215748.000|TR0|
20110103215748.000|20110103215750.000|TR0|HOSTIN:  Well, the law in Wisconsin was 
20110103215750.000|20110103215752.000|TR0|enacted in 1913.  And perhaps, Brooke, 
20110103215752.000|20110103215755.000|TR0|that gives us some insight into why the 
20110103215755.000|20110103215757.000|TR0|compensation level is so low.  Our 
20110103215757.000|20110103215759.000|TR0|economics have changed quite a bit since 
20110103215759.000|20110103215801.000|TR0|1913, and perhaps the law in Wisconsin 
20110103215801.000|20110103215804.000|TR0|needs to catch up with what's going on
